title: Health and Safety Hazards - Environmental Management Systems
headline: Discover the elements of a practical EMS framework for your organization and implement it with this free online course.
description: An environmental management system (EMS) is paramount to any organization’s ability to reduce its ecological footprint. An EMS is a framework of processes and procedures for a company to follow and reduce its impact while increasing its operational performance. This course delves into the basic requirements, policies and planning to help you understand how to monitor and manage an effective EMS for your company.
courseDescription:
An environmental management system (EMS) is a collection of systematic processes and practices that allow a company to reduce its environmental impact while improving its operational efficiency. An EMS is ongoing and knowing its objectives and targets will help you understand its benefits and importance to your company. An EMS is developed and improved in a five-phase cycle. This course will guide you through each phase in detail, to help you build yours to meet the ISO 14001 requirements, an internationally approved standard for an organization’s environmental performance.

The first module will introduce you to the basics of an EMS framework. Here we will briefly touch on the components of a successful EMS, getting support, initial evaluation and policy statements for larger enterprises. Research how to set clear objectives and specific goals to help you create strategies and tactics that would mitigate the negative impacts of company actions, products or services. 

The second module is focused on developing and implementing an EMS program in more detail. We demonstrate who should be involved in the process, compliance, execution and how to monitor the entire process by studying the management review procedure. Environmental challenges can have a considerable impact on any organization. This course will guide you through the entire process involved in successfully implementing an EMS to help your company meet regulatory requirements,and thrive in this green-focused world. Enroll now!

Start Course Now

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • State the critical components of a successful EMS.
    • Identify the international standard for creating and implementing an environmental management system.
    • Evaluate the Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) cycle.
    • Identify the five-phase cycle of the development and improvement of an EMS.
    • Recall the meaning of environmental aspects, impact and objectives.

  • Purpose and Scope of an EMS

  • An Environmental Management System (EMS) is a collection of systematic processes and practices that allow a company to reduce its environmental impact while improving its operational efficiency. The EMS's range will be primarily determined by the operations' context: the company's size, activity, and nature of its products and services.
    • New Tab
      Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • Compliance
      An environmental management system (EMS) assists a company in meeting its environmental compliance obligations methodically and cost-effectively. This proactive strategy can assist in reducing the risk of non-compliance and improve employee and public health and safety standards.

      The idea of an EMS represents a significant shift from traditional reactive, compliance-based environmental management programs toward a proactive, impact-predicting management system centered on company goals and entrenched in daily business processes and activities.
      An environmental management system (EMS) assists a company in meeting its environmental compliance obligations methodically and cost-effectively. This proactive strategy can assist in reducing the risk of non-compliance and improve employee and public health and safety standards.

    • ISO 14001
      The international standard for creating and implementing an environmental management system is ISO 14001. ISO (International Organization for Standardization) publishes the standard. It is an international organization that develops and distributes internationally recognized standards. The most current edition of the environmental management system regulations, known as "ISO 14004:2016," was last reviewed in 2021. Before being released and revised, the standard was agreed upon by a majority of member countries, and as a result, has become an internationally recognized standard acknowledged by a majority of governments throughout the world.

  • Initial Evaluation

  • An Initial Environmental Review (IER) and Gap Analysis (GA) are part of the Baseline Assessment. By conducting the IER, the baseline assessment assists in determining the company's present level of environmental performance and identifying the "gaps" that must be filled to meet ISO 14001 requirements. The baseline evaluation also aids in estimating the costs and people required.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The EMS's Purpose
    Following the completion of the initial baseline assessment, management will determine the scope of the EMS and write the organization's environmental policy statement. The environmental policy will, of course, be based on the organization's visions and objectives.

  • Opportunities and Threats

  • Every company engages in actions that result in various products or services that deal with the physical world. These actions or "aspects" of running a business may have a good, neutral, or negative impact on the environment. However, it's crucial to be aware that parts of doing business might impact the environment locally, nationally, or even globally.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Environmental features and consequences should be examined inside the EMS for the dangers and possibilities they bring. It is important to concentrate on developing an EMS that assists employers in reducing risks and maximizing options that benefit both the firm and the environment.
  • Click on the play button to hear the audio

  • Lesson Summary

  • A summary of the key content covered in the module:
    • The international standard for creating and implementing an environmental management system is ISO 14001.
    • An environmental Management System (EMS) is a collection of systematic processes and practices that allow a company to reduce its environmental impact while improving its operational efficiency.
    • Leadership and commitment are critical components of a successful EMS.
    • Building an Environmental Management System (EMS) - this is a strategy that emphasizes continuous improvement through a sequence of actions known as the Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) cycle.
    • The EMS is developed and improved in a five-phase cycle: Environmental policy, planning phase, implementation phase, inspection and corrective action, and management review stage.
    • An Initial Environmental Review (IER) and Gap Analysis (GA) are part of the Baseline Assessment.
    • Environmental Objectives must be clear and specific goals must be met in order to comply with the Environmental Policy's standards.

  • Lesson Summary

  • A summary of the key content covered in the module:
    • The international standard for creating and implementing an environmental management system is ISO 14001.
    • An environmental Management System (EMS) is a collection of systematic processes and practices that allow a company to reduce its environmental impact while improving its operational efficiency.
    • Leadership and commitment are critical components of a successful EMS.
    • Building an Environmental Management System (EMS) - this is a strategy that emphasizes continuous improvement through a sequence of actions known as the Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) cycle.
    • The EMS is developed and improved in a five-phase cycle: Environmental policy, planning phase, implementation phase, inspection and corrective action, and management review stage.
    • An Initial Environmental Review (IER) and Gap Analysis (GA) are part of the Baseline Assessment.
    • Environmental Objectives must be clear and specific goals must be met in order to comply with the Environmental Policy's standards.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • List possible Environmental Management Programs to include in your organization's EMS.
    • Define the documented and communicated roles, duties, and authorities.
    • Identify the legal and other requirements necessary in the planning step.
    • Discuss the storage of EMS documents that need constant updates.
    • Explain the steps in the Environmental Management Program (EMP) implementation phase.
    • Recognize EMS procedures for checking and corrective action.
    • Outline the useful tools in determining the root causes of problems during the checking and corrective action phases.
    • Summarize the Management Review Procedure, its benefits, and challenges.


  • Introducing the EMP

  • One or more documented Environmental Management Programs (EMPs) inside the EMS are the purpose and end-product of the planning process. Each EMP has formal, detailed sustainability initiatives, processes, procedures, and practices that define how the goals and objectives in a certain environmental area will be met.
  • Click the button for some EMP examples
    ×

    EMP

    Here's a list of possible Environmental Management Programs to include in your facility's EMS:

  • Consider the EMP a formal, organized written document that outlines a strategy for achieving environmental goals and objectives. Typically, the EMP will include information on:

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • Personnel in charge
    • Ways and means of implementation
    • Dates and milestones
    • The ways to measure success
  • In other words, the EMP lays down who will do what, how they'll do it, and when they'll do it.

  • EMP Introduction

  • Now that we've covered the planning step, let's look at the implementation phase. During this step, you will carry out your plans. We'll explore the many aspects of the implementation steps.

    Responsibility and Structure
    The first step is establishing an EMS management structure, including roles and duties. The foundation for this activity is set during the planning phase when environmental management plans are designed to meet specific goals and objectives.

    The steps build upon and support one another. To ensure efficient implementation of the EMS, roles, and duties should be defined, documented, and communicated at all levels.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Job-specific EMS tasks should form a part of each individual's job description to guarantee that EMS roles are established, and associated actions are carried out. Incentives can also be used; for example, some facilities use reward and recognition programs to encourage personnel to achieve EMS criteria.

  • Introduction to Checking and Action Phase

  • Let's go on to the next step in the EMS procedure, which is checking and corrective action. Checking assesses your performance, and corrective action addresses any flaws you find. 
  • Questions to consider are:
    • Are we following through on our promises? Why not?
    • Are we on track to meet our goals and objectives?
    • Is there anything we need to change?

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Checking merely means making sure everything is done and analyzing results if the tracking mechanisms were properly set up throughout the planning and execution processes. This is when everything begins to come together.

    There are four elements to checking and corrective action:
    1. Monitoring and evaluation
    2. Nonconformance, remediation, and prevention
    3. Records
    4. EMS inspection

  • Lesson Summary

  • This topic contains a summary of the key information from this module:
    • Documented Environmental Management Programs (EMPs) inside the EMS are the purpose and end-product of the planning process.
    • An EMP has formal, detailed sustainability initiatives, processes, procedures, and practices that define how to meet the goals and objectives in an environmental area.
    • The Management Representative monitors the EMS and reports on its operation to management.
    • Identifying legal and other requirements is a crucial element of the planning step.
    • The Environmental Management Program implementation consists of the following:
    1. Responsibility and Structure
    2. Awareness, Training, and Competence
    3. Communication
    4. Documentation for EMS
    5. Control of Documents
    6. Control of Operations
    7. Preparedness and Response to Emergencies
